mdRecord.dcterms:title: Holy Trinity Church, interior
Old Swedes Church
mdRecord.dcterms:creator: Wilson, Richard Guy [photographer]
mdRecord.dcterms:publisher: Rector and Visitors of the University of Virginia
mdRecord.dcterms:description: 1899 stained glass window, sanctuary, by William Reith

Holy Trinity Church, also known as Old Swedes Church, in Wilmington, Delaware, is the oldest church in the United States standing as originally built and still in use as a house of worship. It was erected in 1698–1699 by descendents of the Swedish colonists who crossed the Atlantic aboard the Kalmar Nyckel in 1638. The original congregation were associated with the Church of Sweden (Lutheran). The church has housed an Episcopal parish since 1791 and is now part of the Episcopal Diocese of Delaware. Holy Trinity Church was designated a National Historic Landmark November 5, 1961. It was added to the National Register of Historic Places October 15, 1966. The stained glass windows were added in an 1899 reconstruction funded by the Colonial Dames of America. This window is marked "Wm. Reith, Art St'D Glass Mfr., Philadelphia. [work]
